title: Metaligatures
content:
(No, not ligatures for FF Meta...)

One of my fascinations in the field of "visible language" are shapes  
that stand for more than one letter. It's interesting to consider how  
they combine, what parts are "important", and how the recognition of  
the components is weighted (intentionally or not), when alone or even  
more interestingly in the contexts of words. I can't stop thinking of  
this topic, even in banal places like Dairy Queen, where I daydream  
weather a logo that's a "D" with a tail would work (or maybe it would  
drive their loyal customer base back to the mountains.)

Below is something I did when working on Trajic notRoman, years ago.  
But more than show what I've done (not much anyway, really) I'd like  
to collect and compile examples you guys might have seen. Please let  
me know of any metaligatures that you think are worth thinking about!

(Oh, and as always I'm open to terminological  
suggestions as to what to call these things.)

hhp

Here's a logo I designed in 1977.  
 [http://www.oktransportation.com](http://web.archive.org/web/20131105175229/http:/www.oktransportation.com/ "http://www.oktransportation.com")

The idea, which is a mainstay of the "compressed" ligature, is that where there is a repeated vertical stem, one is removed in a kind of "negative kerning" exercise, and the remaining stem does double duty. In a logo, this provides a point of visual interest.

There is a similar idea in the "fi" ligature, where the ball of the f serves as the dot on the "i", but the purpose is different: it could be considered as the removal of visual stutter.

Another category of compressions: as in the Avant Garde ligatures, where the purpose is to enable justification of tight-set headlines.

An ambiligature of ph could be made to resemble an f.
